lines.text: Enter a Carrier with a lantern in his hand

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: Heighho! an it be not four by the day, Ill be hanged: Charles wain is over the new chimney, and yet our horse not packed. What, ostler!

lines.speaker: ostler
lines.text: [Within]   Anon, anon.

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: I prithee, Tom, beat Cuts saddle, put a few flocks in the point poor jade, is wrung in the withers out of all cess.
Enter another Carrier

lines.speaker: second carrier
lines.text: Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog, and that is the next way to give poor jades the bots: this house is turned upside down since Robin Ostler died.

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: Poor fellow, never joyed since the price of oats rose it was the death of him.

lines.speaker: second carrier
lines.text: I think this be the most villanous house in all London road for fleas: I am stung like a tench.

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: Like a tench! by the mass, there is neer a king christen could be better bit than I have been since the first cock.

lines.speaker: second carrier
lines.text: Why, they will allow us neer a jordan, and then we leak in your chimney and your chamberlie breeds fleas like a loach.

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: What, ostler! come away and be hanged!

lines.speaker: second carrier
lines.text: I have a gammon of bacon and two razors of ginger, to be delivered as far as Charingcross.

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: Gods body! the turkeys in my pannier are quite starved. What, ostler! A plague on thee! hast thou never an eye in thy head canst not hear An twere not as good deed as drink, to break the pate on thee, I am a very villain. Come, and be hanged! hast thou no faith in thee
Enter GADSHILL

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Good morrow, carriers. Whats oclock

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: I think it be two oclock.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: I pray thee lend me thy lantern, to see my gelding in the stable.

lines.speaker: first carrier
lines.text: Nay, by God, soft I know a trick worth two of that, i faith.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: I pray thee, lend me thine.

lines.speaker: second carrier
lines.text: Ay, when canst tell Lend me thy lantern, quoth he marry, Ill see thee hanged first.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Sirrah carrier, what time do you mean to come to London

lines.speaker: second carrier
lines.text: Time enough to go to bed with a candle, I warrant thee. Come, neighbour Mugs, well call up the gentleman: they will along with company, for they have great charge.
Exeunt carriers

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: What, ho! chamberlain!

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: [Within]  At hand, quoth pickpurse.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Thats even as fair asat hand, quoth the chamberlain for thou variest no more from picking of purses than giving direction doth from labouring thou layest the plot how.
Enter Chamberlain

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Good morrow, Master Gadshill. It holds current that I told you yesternight: theres a franklin in the wild of Kent hath brought three hundred marks with him in gold: I heard him tell it to one of his company last night at supper a kind of auditor one that hath abundance of charge too, God knows what. They are up already, and call for eggs and butter they will away presently.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Sirrah, if they meet not with Saint Nicholas clerks, Ill give thee this neck.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: No, Ill none of it: I pray thee keep that for the hangman for I know thou worshippest St. Nicholas as truly as a man of falsehood may.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: What talkest thou to me of the hangman if I hang, Ill make a fat pair of gallows for if I hang, old Sir John hangs with me, and thou knowest he is no starveling. Tut! there are other Trojans that thou dreamest not of, the which for sport sake are content to do the profession some grace that would, if matters should be looked into, for their own credit sake, make all whole. I am joined with no footland rakers, no longstaff sixpenny strikers, none of these mad mustachio purplehued maltworms but with nobility and tranquillity, burgomasters and great oneyers, such as can hold in, such as will strike sooner than speak, and speak sooner than drink, and drink sooner than pray: and yet, zounds, I lie for they pray continually to their saint, the commonwealth or rather, not pray to her, but prey on her, for they ride up and down on her and make her their boots.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: What, the commonwealth their boots will she hold out water in foul way

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: She will, she will justice hath liquored her. We steal as in a castle, cocksure we have the receipt of fernseed, we walk invisible.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Nay, by my faith, I think you are more beholding to the night than to fernseed for your walking invisible.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Give me thy hand: thou shalt have a share in our purchase, as I am a true man.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Nay, rather let me have it, as you are a false thief.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Go to homo is a common name to all men. Bid the ostler bring my gelding out of the stable. Farewell, you muddy knave.
Exeunt
